There's also another problem that merging another PR changing the previous or next line in Dependencies.scala causes a conflict in this PR.  It would be nice if Scala Steward would recreate the change on the latest HEAD automatically for this reason as well.  I wonder if we could prevent conflicts in the meantime with next/previous lines by inserting one or two blank lines between every dependency line (is that something pragmatic we could do, or too ugly looking)?

Regarding conflicts, I imagine once we get passed this first round of updates, version bumps should be relatively rare enough and easily/quickly mergable that we can avoid any having multiple PRs open that create conflicts. Seems reasonable that once things are squashd and can be merged then whoever gives the second +1 can just merge right away. I generally like to wait until at least all th checks pass though, so I'll merge once that's the case. Or if you notice it's all green and I forget feel free to merge it.

I think lengthKind="terminator" was a typo. The actual message does correctly have lengthKind="delimited".

The question I had was why does the DFDL spec say ``ES`` can never be used in the ``dfdl:separator`` property, but it can be used in the ``dfdl:terminator`` property as long as it isn't alone as one of the string literals when lengthKind="delimited"? What's the usecase for ever needing ES in ``dfdl:terminator``?

But thinking about it, I guess the usecase is an optional terminator with with non-delimited lengths. So something like ``dfdl:terminator="FOO %ES;"`` seems reasonable when lengthKind is not delimited. So I guess I answered my own question.

So @regetom, I think this does mean we need two separate Cookers. One is needed for cooking separators that is called DelimiterCookerNoES (same as what you have now), and one called something like DelimterCookerNoSoleES which is like the old DelimiterCookerNoES (has no restriction on character class, with the only restriction being sole ES/WSP*).

Saxon provides some detailed information here: https://www.saxonica.com/documentation/#!conditions, which mentions this:

> If you produce a product that includes or requires Saxon-HE, please refer to it prominently as "The Saxon XSLT and XQuery Processor from Saxonica Limited", and include the URL of the home page, which is at http://www.saxonica.com/. As a courtesy, please take reasonable steps to ensure that your users know that they are running Saxon.

So I'd say something like this included in the License section of the README is sufficient:
> This product includes The Saxon XSLT and XQuery Processor from Saxonica Limited (http://www.saxonica.com/), which is licensed under the Mozilla Public License version 2.0.

We might want to consider including something like that in the bin.NOTICE file as well just to be safe. I'm not sure if it's require or not, but seems like it would be.

The above saxonica link also mentions what it calls "Category B" code,  which is code Saxon includes that is not MPL but is compatible (e.g. BSD, MIT, Apache). We don't currently include the licenses of those (and I dont't think we've verified that they are compatiable with Apache, just taking Saxon's word for it). So we need track those down--Saxon mentinos a ``notices`` directory which I can't immediately find but that should have all the information we need to make sure they are all acceptable to ASF, and then we can update our bin.LICENSE/bin.NOTICE appropriately.

I know how to find the `notices` directory.  Go to Saxon 9.9's SourceForge download [page](https://sourceforge.net/projects/saxon/files/Saxon-HE/9.9/), download SaxonHE9-9-1-8J.zip, put it in an empty temporary directory, unpack it, and you will get the `notices` directory.  Five files look like MIT-type copyright notices to me and if we need to include them, then we need to include these five files from that directory into bin.NOTICE (the sixth file is Saxon's license).  

If I understand you correctly, we need to modify the following files:
- README.md (mention Saxon in its License section)
- daffodil-cli/README,md (mention Saxon in its License section)
- daffodil-cli/bin.LICENSE (include Saxon's license)
- daffodil-cli/bin.NOTICE (include five files from Saxon's notices directory)

When we edit bin.NOTICE, shall we insert the five files' text indented by 2 spaces with 1 blank line between each file into bin.NOTICE between "Jackson JSON processor" and "Scala" with the following lines to set them off?

```text
Saxon XSLT and XQuery processor (lib/Saxon-HE-<VERSION>.jar)
  Saxon HE processor
  Copyright (c) 2018 Saxonica Limited.
```

My understanding is that we don't need to include anything in the root README.md, since we don't distribute Saxon in the source, which is what that README talks about. We only distribute Saxon with the CLI, so I think we only need to update ``daffodil-cli/README.md``.

Saxon calls those things in the notice directory "notices", but they are really just licences. My understanding is that license text never goes in the NOTICE file. So all those "notices" from Saxon need to go in the bin.LICENSE files. For that, I would probably include the Saxon license like we include other stuff, and then at the same indention level, nest in the Saxon subcomonent "notices"/licenses, so somthing like:

```
This product bundels Saxon ... available under MPL license:

  Copy MPL license here:

  SAXON SUBCOMPONENTS

  Saxon contains subcomponents with separate coyright noticess....

    Saxon bundles ABC, this is available under the MIT license:
      Copy MIT licnse here

    Saxon bundels XYZ, this is avialabel under the BSD license:
      Copy BSD license here
```

So we sort of have nested licenses so it's clear which parts come from saxon and which parts don't.

I can comment from the DFDL specification and workgroup perspective.

The use case is indeed that where the length kind is something like 'pattern', and depending on the length, a terminator somewhere needs to be present or absent.

This comes up in formats where a string can be say, up to 50 characters long, where if it is exactly 50 characters long, there is no terminator (%ES; case), but if it is less than 50 characters long, a specific character like DEL (x7F) is the terminator. The VMF format (mil-std-6017) is an example of a format that has this kind of strings.

Here's an example:

  <xs:group name="tString50">
    <xs:sequence>
      <xs:element name="value" type="xs:string" dfdl:lengthKind="pattern"
        dfdl:lengthPattern="[^\x7F]{0,49}(?=\x7F)|.{50}" />
      <xs:sequence
        dfdl:terminator="{if (fn:string-length(./value) eq 50) then '%ES;' else '%DEL;'}" />
    </xs:sequence>
  </xs:group>

Note that the regex for the pattern is using look-ahead to see if it finds the DEL terminator or not without consuming it as part of the length. That's the trick here.

The dfdl:separator property does not offer this same possibility of using %ES; because a separator doesn't necessarily act like a terminator, (e.g., separatorPosition 'prefix' is a blend of initiator and terminator) doesn't have many of the associated properties like emptyValueDelimiterPolicy controlling it, but does have entirely different properties related to separator suppression. Disallowing %ES; was just a conservative design choice. In the future it is possible to relax this restriction if all the nuances of property interaction could be worked out. But separators are just so different from terminators that without a compelling use case that cannot be equivalently modeled as terminators, the complexity did not seem worth it.

The error message about terminator cannot be %ES; really should also mention lengthKind="delimited" because when length kind is NOT delimited, %ES; is allowed for terminator.

Actually, I'm wondering if we can just remove this jansi dependency entirely? I don't see any referenes to jansi in the code. The CLI seems to work fine with this dependency removed. All the CLI integration tests pass for me. And I don't think we use ANSI escape codes anywhere, which I think is the purpose of jansi.

Looks like this was added in commit 9c9b1a5dbd00ae488439a167b3c19c9acb1269ce which mentions issus with windows and eclipse? Maybe this solves some issue by just being on the classpath? From the readme of jansi, that doesn't sound like it's the case. Sounds like you have to use some Jansi function for this library to have an affect.

I checked [JLine](https://github.com/jline/jline3)'s README.  It says JLine's dependencies are minimal: we can use JLine without any dependencies on Unix systems, but in order to support Windows, we will need to add either Jansi or JNA.  Further down, it says:

On the Windows platform, relying on native calls is mandatory, so you need to have either Jansi or JNA library in your classpath along with the jline-terminal-jansi or jline-terminal-jna jar. **Failing to do so will create a dumb terminal with no advanced capabilities.**  

I can't see jline-terminal-jansi anywhere in Daffodil, so I think Daffodil has never used Jansi correctly.  If you're fine with the Daffodil debugger acting like a dumb terminal with no advanced capabilities on Windows (I think that's what the above means), we can remove Jansi.

Yeah, it's not clear what a dumb terminal is in widnows. We do use JLine's autocompletion capabilities, I wonder if that is considered "smart" and wouldn't be possible without jansi?

The jline readme does say:
>The big bundle includes everything (except jline-groovy) and is located at: jline/target/jline-${jline.version}.jar

So I think just be depending on jline we get the jline-terminal-jansi functionality, and I guess that finds jansi on the classath and enables things to make the terminal smart in windows? So maybe we are all good, but do need to should keep jansi and keep it updated.

> I removed the call to testRaw from DelimiterCookerNoSoleES. I had to define noCharClassEntities() otherwise the compiler complained that "context" and "raw" did not exist.

I'm not sure why you get this error, but nothing calls ``noCharClassEntities``. You have removed all calls of it, which I think is correct. The ``testRaw`` function is the only that that does anything now. So adding the ``noCharClassEntities`` probably isn't the right solution, and we need to bring the ``testRaw`` function back, since that's what actually does tests.

In your current pull request that you've pushed, if I change
```scala
protected def noCharClassEntities(...)
```
to
```scala
override def testRaw(...)
```
then it compiles without any errors. And if I update ``Cookers.scala`` to use this new cooker:
```scala
object TerminatorCookerNoES extends DelimiterCookerNoSoleES("terminator")
```
and run the test you mention, then I do get the error error:

> The ES entity cannot appear on its own when dfdl:lengthKind="delimited

Which seems right to me. Unfortunately, the test still fails because the TDML test expects ``dfdl:terminator`` in the error message, but that's expected since the new error message no longer includes that information (we should probably add that back to the error message). But with those changes I mentioned, it does seem to be doing the right test and detecting the sole ES.

One additional suggestion that I just noticed: In the new ``DelimiterCookerNoSoleES``, the ``oneLiteralCooker`` member is a ``StringLiteralNoCharClassEntities``. That class implies that there are some char class entities that are never allowed. But that isn't really the case with our new ``NoSoleES`` cooker. That new cooker allows all entities, but just has a special restriction on how some can be used. Since we don't need any of the logic associated with ``StringLiteralNoCharClassEntities``, we should just make it a ``StringLiteralBase``, for the new ``NoSoleES`` cooker:

```scala
  override val oneLiteralCooker: StringLiteralBase =
    new StringLiteralBase(propName, true) {
```

JLine 3 has not only changed its package names, it also has changed some of its classes and their API in some ways.  The Completer classes don't seem to changed their API much (the class names are still there, only in an impl package), but ConsoleReader has become LineReader in a different package with a somewhat different API for building and using it.  The -Djline.terminal=jline.UnixTerminal and -Djline.terminal=jline.UnsupportedTerminal properties are gone and have no replacements in JLine 3 that I can see.  Also, I saw a comment in a Fedora dev list saying recent Scala needs JLine 3.x (Rawhide has 2.x), JLine 3.x needs jansi 2.x (Rawhide has 1.x), and neither JLine nor jansi are backwards compatible with their previous major version.

Daffodil's use of the Completer classes should not be had to port, but its use of the ConsoleReader class looks like it will take some effort to port.  No one seems to have written a guide how to migrate applications from JLine 2's ConsoleReader to JLine 3's LineReader (the closest I found so far was <https://groups.google.com/g/jline-users/c/ebQxEFUVkKs>).  Probably the best way would be to compare JLine 2's [Example](https://github.com/jline/jline2/blob/master/src/test/java/jline/example/Example.java) class with JLine 3's [Example](https://github.com/jline/jline3/blob/master/builtins/src/test/java/org/jline/example/Example.java) class and go from there (also make sure you have the source code to look at too).  If possible, can whoever originally wrote the Daffodil code using ConsoleReader port the code?
Yes, I'll try to get that done today.

I'm concerned about the comment 

> "On the Windows platform, relying on **native calls is mandatory,** so you need to have either Jansi or JNA library in your classpath along with the jline-terminal-jansi or jline-terminal-jna jar. Failing to do so will create a dumb terminal with no advanced capabilities."

in the thread above. Specifically the term *native calls*. 

Different dependencies for Windows/Unix bothers me quite a bit, particularly if we're including windows-specific code that calls native code. 

Are my concerns sensible? I know that deep down, the JVM is making system calls and on Windows those may be different than on Linux. But the JVM itself is different than some dependent libraries to me.

JLine 3 has a [README](https://github.com/jline/jline3#jansi-vs-jna) which goes into more detail.  In short, JLine's TerminalBuilder will select its actual Terminal implementation based on the current operating system and whether you have either a Jansi or JNA library in your classpath.  I'm not too concerned about the dependency on native calls since even sbt requires both JLine 3 and jansi 2 together in its [project/Dependencies.scala](https://github.com/sbt/sbt/blob/develop/project/Dependencies.scala).  

However, I want someone who has used Daffodil's debugger REPL interface many times to verify with some manual testing that this upgrade from JLine 2 and jansi 1 to JLine 3 and jansi 2 hasn't changed Daffodil's terminal behavior in any unexpected way.  The coverage report makes it clear that the CLI integration tests don't test the JLine code paths.  My own manual testing seemed to work fine (tab completion, etc.) but I don't have much experience with Daffodil's debugger mode and the JLine editing key shortcuts.  As long as someone like you does some manual testing before giving another +1, we should be fine.

I took at look at there are some completion things that aren't quite right.

1. For commands that take subcommands (e.g. info, set, display, help), it autocmpletes with with I think an extra escaped space? For example, if you do ``in<TAB>`` it completes to ``info\ ``.  Note that if you then immediately try to ``<TAB> ``, it then lists a some main debugger commands (but not all of them) rather than only listing the things you can get info about. I'm not sure what's causing that.

2. To avoid the above issue, if you do "info <TAB>" to list the things you can get info about, it appears to work, but it also includes some main commands (e.g. break, clear, quit, step). Same thing happens for the "set" command.

3. Some commands autocomplete with those main commands as well that shouldn't have any completions. For example ``condition <TAB>`` lists a bunch of main commands. 

So I think there are two issues here (1) we are adding an escape space in a couple of instances (2) we are sometimes including some main commands in completion candidates when they shouldn't be.
